title: 110_hr3133
content: The Act is titled the "Financial Literacy for Homeowners Act". The Congress finds that expanded access to credit has led to high homeownership rates, but some lenders engage in predatory practices, making it costly for vulnerable families. Borrowers with fair credit can access prime loans with low rates, while those with poor credit resort to subprime loans with higher costs. Predatory lending involves unjustifiably high interest rates and fees in various mortgage products. Predatory lending includes home mortgages, refinancing, equity loans, and repair loans with high interest rates, fees, and unfair terms. These loans have disproportionately affected minority neighborhoods, stripping away wealth accumulated over decades. Vulnerable communities lacking access to traditional institutions are targeted by lenders offering high-interest home equity loans, leading to foreclosure for many homeowners who struggle to meet payments. The joint report by the Department of Housing and Urban Development and the Department of the Treasury in 2000 called for legislation to curb predatory home mortgage lending, including restricting abusive terms, improving consumer literacy and disclosures, and prohibiting government-sponsored enterprises from purchasing predatory loans. The joint report in 2000 proposed a four-point plan to address predatory lending practices, including improving consumer literacy and disclosures, disclosing credit scores to borrowers, and providing timely and accurate information on loan costs. Government agencies are involved in reducing lenders' use of high-pressure sales techniques and misleading borrowers. Predatory lending threatens the work of nonprofit organizations in distressed neighborhoods, and more assistance is needed for borrowers with predatory loans. Nonprofit organizations work with lenders and local governments to improve distressed neighborhoods. More assistance is needed for borrowers with predatory loans, to educate consumers about the dangers of home loans, and to refer them to appropriate agencies for help. Grant program established for education and counseling on predatory lending. The Secretary of the Treasury may provide grants to States, local governments, and nonprofits for anti-predatory lending activities. These activities include education programs to inform vulnerable consumers about unfair lending practices and counseling programs offered by certified organizations. The Secretary of the Treasury provides grants for anti-predatory lending activities, including education and counseling programs offered by certified organizations to inform consumers about unfair lending practices and provide referrals for assistance. Eligibility for grants is open to States, local governments, and nonprofits. To be eligible for a grant under this section, a State, local government, or nonprofit organization must submit an application to the Secretary with required information. The maximum grant amount for any single grantee in a fiscal year is $1,000,000. The Secretary will select grant recipients based on established criteria. The Secretary will establish a toll-free telephone number for predatory lending complaints, provide information, refer borrowers to assistance, and coordinate with organizations. The toll-free line will only be operated by actual persons. Additionally, a Predatory Lending Advisory Council will be created. Established in the Department of the Treasury is a Predatory Lending Advisory Council (referred to as the "Council") to advise the Secretary on predatory and unscrupulous lending practices related to home loans. The Council consists of 13 members appointed by the Secretary, including representatives of community-based organizations, State consumer affairs officials, and private homeowners familiar with home mortgages. The Predatory Lending Advisory Council in the Department of the Treasury consists of 13 members appointed by the Secretary, including representatives from community-based organizations, State consumer affairs officials, private homeowners familiar with home mortgages, and the private real estate industry. Members serve two-year terms, with initial appointments split between one and two years. They receive travel expenses but no compensation. The Secretary designates a chairperson, and the Council meets at the chairperson's call, with a minimum of 3 meetings. The Predatory Lending Advisory Council in the Department of the Treasury consists of 13 members appointed by the Secretary, including representatives from various organizations. The Council meets at least 3 times per year and has the authority to hold public hearings. It provides advice to the Secretary on grant programs, toll-free telephone numbers, coordination of activities, and other matters related to predatory lending practices. The Predatory Lending Advisory Council conducts a study on the root causes of default and foreclosure of home loans, using empirical data. A report with recommendations for consumer protection legislation is submitted to the Secretary and Congress within 12 months of the Council's appointment. SEC. 6. DEFINITIONS. The definitions under this Act include the terms "home loan," "nonprofit organization," and "predatory or unscrupulous lending practice." A home loan refers to a loan secured by residential property, while a nonprofit organization is defined as per the Cranston-Gonzalez National Affordable Housing Act. Predatory lending practices encompass making loans that are exploitative or unethical. The term "predatory or unscrupulous lending practice" includes making loans solely based on home equity without considering the borrower's ability to repay, inducing repeated refinancing with additional fees, and engaging in fraud or deception. The term "predatory or unscrupulous lending practice" includes inducing repeated refinancing with additional fees and engaging in fraud or deception to conceal the true nature of the loan obligation. SEC. 7. Authorization of appropriations for the Act is $55,000,000 annually from 2008 to 2012, with specific allocations for sections 4 and 5. SEC. 8. The Secretary has the authority to issue regulations for implementing the Act.
